document.docAuthor: Martínez, Leonel, Brescovit, Antonio D. & Quijano, Luis G.
document.docTitle: Tenedos carlosprietoi Martínez & Brescovit & Quijano 2022, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Revealing the diversity of ant-eating spiders in Colombia I: morphology, distribution and taxonomy of the barronus group of the genus Tenedos O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1897 (Araneae: Zodariidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revealing the diversity of ant-eating spiders in Colombia I: morphology, distribution and taxonomy of the barronus group of the genus Tenedos O. Pickard-Cambridge, 1897 (Araneae: Zodariidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype : COLOMBIA . Meta : San Juanito , Vereda Plan de San Luis , Parque Nacional Natural Chingaza , San José , Andean forest and Páramo , Pitfall trap ,
2990m
[ 4°29′38″N , 73°41′33″W ], L. Quintero & M. Torres leg.,
22-24.XI.2003
, 1 ♂ (IAvH-I-605)
.
Paratypes : same data as the holotype, 1 ♀ (IAvH-I-3007), 1 ♀ (IAvH- I-3008), 1 ♀ (IAvH-I-3009). Cundinamarca : Caseta , Parque Nacional Natural Chingaza , Andean forest fragment, Pitfall trap ,
3025m
[ 4°31′N , 73°45′W ], A. Cifuentes leg.,
22-28.VIII.2003
, 1 ♂ (IAvH-I-606), 1 ♀ (IAvH-I-614)
.
Etymology. The specific epithet is a patronymic in honor of the eminent lepidopterologist Carlos Prieto, by his many contributions to the taxonomy and systematic of the family Lycaenidae .

Diagnosis. Males of
Tenedos carlosprietoi
sp. n.
, resemble those of
T. andes Jocqué & Baert, 2002
and
T. medina
sp. n.
, by presence of basal retrolateral tibial apophysis (bRTA), rounded median apophysis (MA) (see Jocqué & Baert, 2002: 83 , fig. 7A–B; figs 94A–D; 95A–B; 97A–D, 98A–B; 99A–F; 101A–D; 102A–B; 104A–D), but can be distinguished by larger median apophysis, apically bifid basal retrolateral tibial apophysis; wider retrolateral tibial apophysis (RTA) ( Figs 101A–D ; 102A–B ; 104A–D ). Females are similar to those of
Tenedos andes Jocqué & Baert, 2002
and
T. medina
sp. n.
, by the large median field plate (MFP) ( Figs 94E–F ; 95C–D ; 97E–F , 98C–D ; 101E–F ; 102C–D ; 104E–F ), but can be recognized by longer than wide, cylindrical-shaped atrium (A), very wider seminal receptacles (SR), ending at anterior region of median septum of epigyne, wider and longer lateral borders (LB) ( Figs 101E–F ; 102C–D ; 104E–F ).

Tenedos carlosprietoi
sp. n. A–B.
Male habitus (IAvH-I-605): A. Dorsal view. B. Ventral view. C–D. Female habitus (IAvH-I-3007): C. Dorsal view. D. Ventral view. Scale bar: A–D: 2mm.

Tenedos carlosprietoi

Tenedos carlosprietoi

Abbreviations: A, atrium; bRTA, basal retrolateral tibial apophysis; E, embolus; FD, fertilization ducts; LB, lateral borders; MA, median apophysis; MFP, median field plate; RTA, retrolateral tibial apophysis; S, spermathecae; SR, seminal receptacles.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Variation. Males (n=3): total length: 6.57–7.32; carapace length: 3.33–3.53; femur I length: 1.09–1.92. Females (n=3): total length: 5.53–6.48; carapace length: 3.27–3.48; femur I length: 0.99–1.97. Population of
Tenedos carlosprietoi
sp. n.
distributed in Cundinamarca department exhibits the following variations in both sexual and somatic features: the prosome present lighter color tonalities, the anterior abdominal scutum is wider and longer ( Fig. 103A–D ), and the variation of spines patterns is I—tibia v1r-1r-1p; II—tibia v1r-1r-1r; IV—tibia v2-2-2. Retrolateral tibial apophysis longer, apically sharp, very short and lightly apically bifid retrolateral tibial apophysis ( Fig. 104A–D ). Females are presenting a shorter atrium and lateral borders and longer seminal receptacles ( Fig. 104E–F ).
Distribution. Known from Cundinamarca and Meta departments, Colombia ( Fig. 106 ).
